newsitem.title: USA: U.S. fed cattle numbers seen above year ago.
newsitem.headline: U.S. fed cattle numbers seen above year ago.

text.p: The number of cattle in major U.S. feedlots in December exceeded last year's levels because profit margins remained strong and feed prices continued to slide, livestock analysts said.
The U.S. Agriculture Department is expected to confirm the expected jump in supplies on Friday in its monthly Cattle on Feed Report, set for release at 1400 CST/2000 GMT.

Analysts projected the data will show the number of cattle on feed in feedlots of 1,000 head or more capacity in the seven key states on January 1 at 104.2 percent of a year ago, in a range of 102.0 to 105.0.

December placements ranged widely and this part of the report was seen by some as the most important data. Estimates averaged 108.2 percent of a year ago in a Reuter pre-report survey of analysts, and ranged from 103.0 to 112.0 percent.

"When you look at the kind of environment we had in December, I think the cheaper feed was still an incentive for people to put cattle on feed," said Tom Tippens, chief executive officer of Professional Cattle Consultants Inc based in Weatherford, Okla.
Tippens noted that along with lower feed costs, cattle were still selling for high prices in early December which created incentive to put cattle on feed.
He estimated placements at 110.8 percent, which is the top of the range of placement estimates.
Other analysts see the trend for placements to exceed year-ago levels coming to an end following the USDA December data.
"We delayed placements when corn was at four and five dollars (per bushel)," said Ron Plain, senior livestock economist at the University of Missouri.
"The calves that didn't go on feed then went on feed this fall, but we're starting to work through those (cattle)."
Plain said the industry "can't just continue to increase the number of cattle on feed forever," and said a slowdown in placements was imminent.
Analysts said December marketings data will reflect brisk cattle sales as feedlots worked to stay current. Marketing estimates averaged 101.8 percent, ranging from 99.0 to 107.1 percent.
Tippens was also at the high end of estimates on marketings, projecting marketings at 107.1 percent.
"We just had tremendous movement of these fed cattle out of the yards that I do business with," he said.

Jim Robb, analyst at the Livestock Marketing Information Center in Denver, forecast December marketings to fall below year-ago levels, but said that figure should not be considered bearish. He estimated marketings at 99 percent of a year ago.
"Marketings were down because cattle supplies were very tight," Robb said. "It was mostly a function of the cattle just not being there and ready to go."

Analysts continued to estimate only the seven-state part of the report with feedlots over 1,000 head even though USDA began a 12-state report more than a year ago. More time was needed to compare historical data, they said.
